title: Horn

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of wood, copper alloy, and iron.

artist_display:
Kuba
Kasai region, Democratic Republic of the Congo
Central Africa
description: Drinking horns and cups are among the many insignia that have denoted status in the highly hierarchical Kuba society since the kingdom’s foundation in the 17th century. This wooden sculpture—decorated with raised geometric and figural designs—imitates the horn of a buffalo, an animal that stands for the powerful, untamed wilderness and is therefore associated with both rulers and warriors.
publication_history:
Alain Locke. Blondiau-Theatre Arts Collection of Primitive African Art (introduction), exh. cat (New York: The New Art Circle/Theater Arts Monthly, 1927), cat. no. 156.

Alain Locke. "A Collection of Congo Art" in The Arts 11, 2 (1927), pp. 61-70 (ill.).

Harlem Museum of African Art, The Negro in Art Week: Nov. 16 -23, exh. cat.  (Art Institute of Chicago, 1927), cat. 3 (ill.). 

Helen F. MacKenzie. “A Group of Primitive Carvings in Wood and Horn,” in Bulletin of the Art Institute of Chicago 24, 1 (Jan. 1930.) p. 8-9, 6 (object mentioned, illustrated p. 16).

Richard F. Townsend and Kathleen Bickford Berzock, “The Art Institute of Chicago New Galleries for African Art and Indian Art of the Americas,” in Tribal Arts XVI:1, 62 (Winter 2011), p. 60, fig. 3.

Kathleen Bickford Berzock, “Changing Place, Changing Face: A History of African Art at the Art Institute of Chicago,” in Representing Africa in American Art Museums: A Century of Collecting and Display, ed. Katheleen Bickford Berzock and Christa Clarke (University of Washington Press, 2010), pp. 150-167 (ill. fig 7.3).

Constantine Petridis et al., Speaking of Objects: African Art at the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2020), cat. no. 58, pp. 144-145 (ill.).
exhibition_history:
New York, The New Art Circle, Bondiau-Theatre Arts Collection of Primitive African, Feb. 7-March 5, 1927, cat. no. 156 (not illustrated).

Children’s Museum at the Art Institute of Chicago, The Negro in Art Week: Primitive and Modern, lent by Harlem Museum of African Art [Blondiau Collection of African Art], Nov. 16-Dec. 1, 1927, cat. 3 (ill.); traveled to Rochester, N.Y., the Memorial Art Gallery.

Iowa, Junior Art Museum of Des Moines, Baga to Batabwo: Safari in Art, Oct. 19–Dec. 9, 1958.

West Lafayette, Ind., Purdue University Department of Creative Arts, African Art, April 6-28, 1970.
provenance_text: Raoul Blondiau, Brussels, Belgium, by 1925 [acquired between 1900 to 1925 according to Blondiau-Theatre Arts Collection, exh. cat., 1927]; sold to Theatre Arts, Inc. (Theatre Arts Monthly), New York, N.Y., Nov. 1926 [according to Blondiau-Theatre Arts Collection, exh. cat.1927; Deacon 1981]; sold to the Art Institute, 1928.
